text: a little bit actually about your life
growing up I think a lot of people
outside of Texas don't know about your
mom and and and and what she did well my
mother is probably the biggest reason
that that my brother and I are in public
service she ran for City Council in 1971
when she was 23 her pride is a pride not
just in in me and my brother it's also a
pride in how far the country has come
what is the message that the party is is
sending by having you give this pivotal
sort of speech the message is that the
American Dream is alive and well and
that no matter where we come from and
what our background is that this is the
land of opportunity and that President
Obama is making the right investments so
that America continues to be the land of
opportunity and continues as globally
you
yeah that feels very far off
it's very flattering but I wouldn't put
myself in the same league with the
president I'm a mayor of a city and I'm
not running for anything more than being
mayor right now what's it like you know
being one of the most respected and
popular Democrats and in Texas what's it
like being in that role in a overall
state that is dominated by the Republic
has some days it's a little depressing
but you know I'm in a non-partisan role
here as mayor and I really enjoyed being
in that nonpartisan role in fact I'm
convinced that one of the reasons that
the local level a lot more still gets
done is because you know there's not
always the need to to tow a party line
most folks don't realize how far to the
right Texas is we have 29 statewide
offices and the count between
Republicans and Democrats is 29
Republicans and 0 Democrats in statewide
office there's a super majority of
Republicans in the state house and one
short of a supermajority in the state
Senate and so for Democrats in the
coming years whoever it is that that you
know comes along and wants to change
that what they need to point out to the
population is since when is it healthy
at all for you to be at one extreme
wouldn't a little bit of balance
you
what does it mean to them I hope that
it'll be a source of real pride for the
folks here in San Antonio you know when
my brother and I went away to to
Stanford into Harvard Law School we were
amazed by the people that we met but
both of us came away with this sense
that there were many people that we had
grown up with in the west side of San
Antonio and the public schools that if
they'd had the right opportunity could
have been in those seats at both of
those places and so I hope when when
young folks watch me on September forth
from here they'll feel like you know
that I can do that there's nothing out
of the ordinary there I can accomplish
that and that more of them in the future
will
